2.description: The room is silent. You feel about for the light switch. You find it, and gently press it on. Oops! It’s Mrs. Harding’s room! What a mistake! You see her turn and rise from the bedclothes, her frightened face screaming. As the scream pierces your ears, you hear the boarders begin to stir. The residents are coming! But what’s focusing your attention is the shotgun Mrs. Harding is reaching for. You’d better run!

3.description: Deposits and withdrawals are possible between 9-3. M-F. If you’re Prof. Grunewald, your account is here, and you can withdraw up to the Cash amount noted on the investigator sheet.
3.title: ARKHAM FIRST NATIONAL BANK

7.description: The window opens smoothly, and you enter. You try to move as quietly as possible.

choices.text: Try to run past the man

7a.description: You realize that you have no idea where Gliere's room is. You go upstairs. All the doors are closed; none have names on them.

9.description: The man is an Egyptian. His posture seems threatening.

choices.text: Try to run past the man

11.description: Before you enter, you sense something beyond the door. Putting your ear to the door, you listen.

13.description:
For you, Professor Louis Grunewald, this first day of September 1931 has been tiring and uncomfortable. Light mist has covered Arkham for most of the day. You held two uninspired undergraduate classes at Miskatonic University, and you met with the new chairman of the literature Department, a giddy Technocrat. You survey your desk and see that a stack of papers to grade has already formed. You’re enjoying your second pipe of the evening, and putting off grading papers, when the doorbell rings. To your surprise, it’s a telegraphic messenger.

“It arrived at Kingspoint Head station not more than an hour ago,” the boy says.

You sign for it, and slip a dime into the youngster’s hand. “Oh, thank you, sir!” You open the envelope and scan the contents (Handout: Dark 1, see page 12).

My goodness, you think. Imagine! Dotty old Gliere in prison! You recall that he had gone to Greece to work on his book concerning primitive myths. What has he gotten himself into? Should you wire money? You recall all the amusing discussions you’ve had with him, and a sudden insight lets you understand that Tibor Gliere had no close friends except for you. Should you go help him? You suppose the University will grant you leave. But do you want to go?

With uncommon speed you decide to go to Athens to help Gliere. You write him a wire, and another to Ernest Holt, a wealthy New York financier and a good friend of yours. If you get into hot water, Holt will help, and so, you decide to keep him posted on your progress. You give both telegrams to the waiting messenger, along with the necessary funds.

What to do now? You’ll go to the bank first thing in the morning to get travel funds. As for Trans-Atlantic schedules, well the Advertiser surely carries that information. As you pack, you wonder if you should check Gliere’s room at Mrs. Harding’s boarding house. Maybe you could get a clue about Gliere’s activities or a hint about his arrest.

Your passport is in order; your clothes and sundries are packed. You’d best turn in. You’re going on a little trip. When you awake, it is Sept. 2; go to 102.
13.title: START

16.description:
If arriving in Arkham, go to any Arkham Location.

If heading to Boston, the trip takes an hour.
16.title: ARKHAM DEPOT

23.description: “Don’t try and flim-flam me! This is my boarding house and I’ll allow in whom I wish!” She slams the door.

choices.text: Try sneaking in later at night

24.description: This constellations map is quite similar to the copy of Ptolemy’s found in the Miskatonic University collection. Strangely enough, the star patterns here are slightly twisted or even completely skewed. In fact some stars are missing completely.

28.description: The door is locked. If you want to try the window, go to 7. If you want to pick its lock, make a successful Locksmith or Hard Mechanical Repair roll. If you want to pry open the window, succeed at an STR roll.

choices.text: Pry open the window with an STR roll

28a.description: You've managed to enter the Harding House without causing too much disturbance. Now, you must navigate quietly.

choices.text: Attempt Stealth to scout the house
Go to any New York Location

36.description: Something is wrong. You learned long ago to trust your hunches. Grunewald’s telegrams stopped without explanation 72 hours ago; your inquiries have gone unanswered. Should you alert your agents scattered across the globe? Judiciously sipping superb brandy, at last you decide against the employment of proxies. Grunewald hinted of mysteries beyond the capacities of mere assistants. You trust his judgment and decide to go yourself. You scrawl instructions to subordinates and dictate phone messages to a secretary whom you have callously woken from a sound sleep. Your holdings will tend themselves for a few weeks. Your passport is in order. You’ll pull strings to get an assortment of visas overnight: mere governments cannot keep Ernest Holt from aiding a friend. A liner sails soon. Jenkins can have you packed and ready to go in an hour. You have plenty of time. It’s a pity your experimental trans-Atlantic passenger plane isn’t quite ready, though that would be fun! You find yourself eagerly anticipating action in the field. You feel ready for anything. You call Lydia Lau at The New York Sun. A despicable rag of a newspaper, but a crackerjack young lady with lots of talent. Miss Lau has heard nothing from Grunewald. You notice her professional interest grow as you talk, and you ask her to write nothing for a few days. “I’m sure there’s a proper explanation,” you say grandly, but somehow you know that neither of you believes that statement. Now you sleep. You’ll attend to details tomorrow. When you wake, go to any New York Location.
36.title: ERNEST HOLT’S APARTMENT

choices.text: Go to any New York Location

37.description: You flirted with the City Editor, and then polished up the National Editor. As usual, your skills and your baby-blues got you what you wanted, and you don’t mind giving an old goat a lift now and then. Besides, this could be the biggest story of your young life, or so you hope. Headlines sail through your imagination: “MISKATONIC MYSTERY!” “GAL GUMSHOE TRACKS DOWN MISSING PROFESSOR!” “FINANCIER FOUND ALIVE!” And your by-line is under every one. With Gliere dead, and Holt and Grunewald missing, you’re pretty sure that the story behind this one will be a real jaw-dropper— and probably dangerous. Holt’s been missing for 72 hours. You thoughtfully pack the gigantic revolver given to you by Bruno the vice-squad cop. A girl can’t be too careful, you decide. You can leave soon on one of the regular liners, and in the meantime do some shopping and research—maybe even make a trip to Arkham. You send a telegram to your beau, Devon Wilson, aboard the USS Rochester, telling him your plans and that you’ll keep in touch. The Sun’s circulation boost from this story should blow that pipsqueak Daily News right out of the water, you dreamily calculate. As for you, it’ll be goodbye New York—hello Pulitzer Prize! In the morning, go to any New York Location.
37.title: Lydia Lau's Apartment

38.description: This retailer accepts currency from any country.
38.title: RETAIL STORE

48.description: “Aristotle Mylonas, Director of the National Museum of Archaeology in Athens, died today in a bizarre automobile accident. His car, apparently going much too fast, spun through the railing of a stone bridge across the Illissus River. This internationally known scholar, largely responsible for the protection of many Greek national treasures, will be sorely missed. A reclusive man, Mylonas was unmarried and without other family. He declared always that his beloved Greece was both mother and father to him.”—Arkham Advertiser, July 1, 1931

60.description: You can look up scheduled sailings. You notice a newspaper with news of Athens. For each hour spent browsing through the paper’s back-issue files, you can attempt one of the following rolls once.
60.title: ARKHAM ADVERTISER

80.description: “In a gala ceremony, Zeno Pisistratos was installed as curator of the National Museum of Archaeology at Athens today. Pisistratos, an expert in Greek and Egyptian antiquities, is said to be interested in arranging exchange-exhibits with other important world museums.” —Arkham Advertiser, July 20, 1931.

82.description: The MU library is open 9am to 9pm, Mon-Sat.
82.title: MISKATONIC UNIVERSITY

102.description: If it is after 8 September, go to 147. If not, and if you’re Grunewald, you can rest and have a repast: go to any Arkham Location. If you’re not Grunewald, go to 120.
102.title: GRUNEWALD'S HOME

113.description: Mrs. Harding greets you amiably. She is uncertain whether she should show you Gliere’s room.
113.title: HARDING HOUSE

125.description: “Greek sponge divers have recovered a puzzling device off the island of Karpathos, a small island between Crete and Turkey. The device is a mechanism believed to be thousands of years old, yet bright and untarnished, as though made yesterday. Scientists have declined comment on the metal from which the device is made. Archaeological experts from the National Museum have taken possession of the oddity for further study.”—Arkham Advertiser, June 8, 1900.

136.description: A Cunard liner departs Pier 56 in New York City every Saturday for Athens and Alexandria, with intermediate stops. The trip takes nine days to Athens and one more to Alexandria.

168.description: The archaeological team at the National Museum in Athens have reported on the Karpathos Device, noting the inexplicable markings on its surfaces and the complex network of gears and linkages. The team has established that the Device is at least 2,000 years old, although some suggest it might hold a more ancient date. The report implies an ancient level of technical achievement previously undreamt of by scholars. Cryptic Greek inscriptions were found on the outside edges of some gears, while some interior sections were marked with unusual Egyptian hieroglyphics. The team makes no guess about the function of the Device.

172.description: Tibor Gliere’s suicide stunned Miskatonic University. The disappearance of Professor Grunewald under suspicious circumstances has set rumors flying. Dean Wilcox is puzzled, upset, and unwilling to give an interview, but his secretary confides that Dean Wilcox hasn’t a clue as to what is going on.

176.description: You see the fabulous treasures of ancient Greece. You also find the stand where the Karpathos Device, replaced at the moment by a drawing and a photograph, is normally kept. The notes speculate that the Karpathos Device is some kind of astronomical clock designed to aid priests. Other scholars feel it may have been designed to actually create something material. Still others see it as merely an elaborate amusement for some wealthy noble or merchant. The origin of the device is not uncertain, nor has the substance of which it is made been determined.

choices.text: Learn more information on the Device.

206.title: CAIRO MUSEUM
206.description: The museum is open 9am to noon, and from 3pm-6pm daily. Three exhibits in this great museum might interest you:

209.description: The Karpathos Device is there, with interesting background information. Its appearance is remarkably modern, resembling aluminum but obviously of great strength. Its enclosure is electrically guarded to prevent theft. Need a refresher on the Karpathos Device?

choices.text: Refresh your memory about the Device.
Back to the main area of the museum.
Explore other ideas about the Device.

211.description: Having come so far and seen much danger, you believe the fate of the world might depend on your actions. How could you not attempt to secure the Karpathos Device?

choices.text: Hide until the museum closes and then attempt the theft.

229.description: The Karpathos Device is secured within a thick glass enclosure with an alarm system. What do you do?

263.description: In the dim yellow night-lights of the museum, you can scarcely believe your eyes. The place has come alive with undead in many forms: from human mummies to megatheria in the natural history wing, all bizarrely returned to life! Everywhere you see the ominous, jerky shuffle of half-dead things. Instinctively you understand that these entities want to snuff out your life and baffle your purpose. You edge quietly along the halls, intent upon your escape from this hair-raising peril. To escape, you need to make successful Spot Hidden, Dodge, and INT rolls respectively, without missing any of the rolls.

263a.description: You focus intently, trying to spot a safe path through the menacing shadows.

failure.message: A mummy's hand brushes against you as you fail to notice a crucial detail!

263b.description: Having spotted a possible path, you now need to dodge the groping hands of the undead.

failure.message: You stumble as a hand clutches at your foot, causing minor injuries!

263c.description: One last challenge: apply your intellect to find the safest exit route.

success.message: You hurl yourself through a plate glass window to escape, suffering cuts in the process.

failure.message: A wrong turn! You're swiped by a clawed appendage as you miscalculate your route.

274.description: Police cars come screeching up to the museum. You have several options, and should think about them all before choosing one:

choices.text: Talk your way out of this
Persuade them that you belong here
Admit your actions to the police

276.description: But what is that sound you hear? Terror clutches your heart.

280.description: There is toughened glass around the Karpathos Device. Perhaps you have a tool or weapon, or something you can throw at it?

281.description: You decide to wait out the closing hours hidden in the shadows of the museum. If you fail, you will be ushered out.

293.description: You have evaded several of the guards and the Karpathos Device is in your possession, decide your next action carefully.

choices.text: Decide what to do with the Device

301.description: You've managed to escape with the Device. Now you must decide how to proceed.

choices.text: Proceed with your escape, go to 293.
Surrender to the authorities, go to 315.

315.description: You come forward, turn yourself into the police and confess everything. The Karpathos Device is taken from you and you rot in a hellish sanatorium for a long time. Eventually you are released.

choices.text: Go to any New York Location

554.description: Your ship, the USS Rochester, lies snugly at anchor. Ordinarily, as the dashing Lt. Devon Wilson, you’d be storming the gangplank to start your month’s leave with a spree, but Nora’s alarming telegrams abruptly stopped exactly seven days ago, while you were still at sea. You must find her. You study her photo in its Deco frame and then carefully pack it. You’d give everything you have to get her back. As you pack, a chill runs down your spine: Gliere was a suicide, Grunewald and Holt mysteriously lost, and now Nora! You decide to include your service revolver in your bags, and you resolve to equip yourself for any eventuality at that nearby store. The Rochester is in the port location you wish; choose from: New York, Athens, Alexandria, or Bremen. Pick up any equipment or supplies you want and then go to any location below.
554.title: USS Rochester

574.description: You have failed! Depending where you are, your experiences vary. Coastline lines suffer dramatic flooding and panic ensues. Scientists claim the Earth has somehow shifted on its axis and that terrible consequences will follow. Indeed, they do. Storms of primeval force sweep the continents. Melting polar ice fuels the flooding, while terrifying ice storms strike at the heart of civilization. Once it begins, much of the world of humankind is destroyed within days. The City of the Old Ones has a new master, and the whole world pays for your failure. Your revolver has a bullet in the chamber. Whether you choose to use it or not, it is ... THE END.

choices.text: End the game, reflecting on the outcomes of your choices.

585.title: HOSPITAL
585.description: You get tender loving care at the hospital. Make a Luck roll to see how well you recover.

choices.text: Make a Luck roll for recovery

success.message: Your recovery is swift and effective. You gain 2D3 hit points for the first day.

failure.message: Recovery is slow, but you still gain 1D3 hit points for the first day.

585a.description: You feel much better but can still recover more.

choices.text: Stay another day to regain 1 hit point (up to your normal maximum)

585b.description: Your condition is stable, but additional rest could help.

choices.text: Stay another day to regain 1 hit point (up to your normal maximum)

585_exit.description: You decide it's time to leave the hospital. Where to next?

593.description: A small diner offering basic meals. It's a place to sit down and have a meal while gathering your thoughts.
593.title: BEE'S DINER

230_guard_1_action.description: The first guard reacts. Roll 1D6 to determine the guard's action.

6.description: The first guard attempts to grab you.

1-5.description: The first guard shoots at you, causing 1D8 damage.

230_guard_1_combat.description: The first guard has grabbed you! Fight back with the Karpathos Device or try to dodge.

230_guard_2_action.description: Now, you face the second guard. Roll 1D6 to see his reaction.

6.description: The second guard attempts to grab you.

1-5.description: The second guard shoots at you, causing 1D8 damage.

230_guard_2_combat.description: The second guard has grabbed you! Decide your next move.

230_guard_3_action.description: You now confront the third and final guard. Roll 1D6 to determine his actions.

6.description: The third guard tries to grab you.

1-5.description: The third guard shoots, causing 1D8 damage, but you escape his pursuit!

230_guard_3_combat.description: The final guard has made his move to grab you. How will you respond?

choices.text: Use the Karpathos Device to fight

230a.description: The glass shatters loudly as you grab the Karpathos Device. It is surprisingly heavy. Unfortunately, the noise attracts immediate attention. Make a DEX check to see if you can escape before the guard unstraps his revolver and takes a shot at you.

choices.text: Attempt to escape with the Device, make a DEX check.

230b.description: You sprint through the halls, evading the guard. As you turn a corner, you face the first of three more guards stationed in successive rooms.

230c.description: The guard fires his revolver. Take 1D8 damage if he hits. If you survive, you must still try to escape through the museum.

choices.text: Continue to flee despite the injury.

230d.description: You are now facing the first guard. Roll 1D6 to determine the guard's action.

230e.description: After dealing with the first guard, you now face the second guard.

230f.description: Having navigated past the second guard, you now face the third and final guard.

249a.description: The authorities are hot on your trail, your fate hangs in the balance.

choices.text: Resist arrest and try to escape.
Attempt to destroy the Karpathos Device.

249b.description: You find that the Device is impervious to your hasty assaults. But the Nile is only a few paces distant. You consider whether to throw it into the river to prevent its misuse.

choices.text: Throw the Device into the Nile.
Reconsider and surrender to the police.

249c.description: You steal a felucca and slowly drift downstream. Sometime later you judge it safe, and drop the heavy Device into the Nile itself, so that it will sink down into the deep silts that have lain there undisturbed for millennia. Later, the police find you and capture you. You serve seven years in an Egyptian prison, only to return home penniless, disgraced, and without home or friends. Your life is ruined, and until you die you never know whether you did the right thing in Cairo all those years before. But you did, of course. Well done! You saved the world. THE END.

249d.description: It doesn't take long for the police to surround you and reclaim the Karpathos Device. As for you, the police arrest you and you spend several years in prison, before being released and returned to America.
